awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  New dwarfing genes to improve yield and abiotic stress tolerance in wheat
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be to improve wheat yield globally by deploying newly developed, region-specific dwarfing genes. World population is predicted to grow to 9.6 billion by 2050. Wheat demand is expected to increase also due to a shift from rice to wheat consumption due to an expected increase in wealth around the globe. The increased wheat demand will have to be met under less land area and changing climate. Water use efficiency and increase in wheat yields will be important factors in meeting this demand. The proposed technology is poised to increase wheat yield under abiotic stress conditions. All of these benefits are expected to have a major positive impact on humanity.  The wheat seed business is currently valued at up to $8.3 billion. The proposed technology will provide a competitive advantage to capture a significant market share of the wheat seed industry while contributing positively towards food security during the changing climate.

This SBIR phase II project proposes to further develop and test alternative dwarfing genes to improve wheat yield and abiotic stress tolerance around the globe. Responsible for the "green-revolution," dwarfing genes are required to obtain higher yields, but the two dwarfing genes present in more than 90% of the currently grown wheat varieties have serious ill-effects including abiotic stress sensitivity, reduced root length and biomass, seedling emergence, and vigor. During the Phase I research, four new dwarfing genes were identified and shown to be significantly better than the currently used genes. Phase II will focus on the comparison of the new genes with the old genes to show their true benefits. This research also will generate valuable data required for the development of "release-ready" varieties.  Genetic background effects will be studied by transferring one of the new dwarfing genes into two different backgrounds followed by field and controlled condition evaluation. Future competitive advantage will be maintained by pyramiding the new dwarfing genes with complementary gene action. Closely linked DNA markers will be developed for an efficient transfer of the technology into diverse backgrounds.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
World population is predicted to cross 9.6 billion by 2050. Food demand of the increased population will have to be met under less land area. Additionally, the availability of fresh water will continue to decrease and be a serious/critical concern in the coming years. Thus, water use efficiency and any increase in the crop yields per unit land will be of tremendous help in coping with the population growth. Currently, wheat provides about 35% of the calories to the world population, second to rice and this proportion is expected to increase. This is due to expected increase in wealth which directly correlates with a transition from rice to wheat use. Previous efforts to increase wheat yield lead to the discovery and utilization of dwarfing genes and were responsible for bringing about the ?green-revolution?.  However, the two dwarfing genes present in more than 90% of the currently grown wheat varieties worldwide have serious ill-effects including abiotic stress sensitivity, reduced root length and biomass, seedling emergence and vigor, and others. This Small Business Innovation Research project has successfully performed the research, development, and marketing necessary to alleviate the ill-effects of the current dwarfing genes. The outcomes of this project include discovery of seven new dwarfing genes each ideally suited for a particular wheat growing condition. Furthermore. specific DNA markers for each of the seven dwarfing genes were developed which will be critical for the selection of the dwarfing genes during their transfer to various backgrounds. Additionally, eight wheat variety candidates have been developed that are at various stages of seed increase or release process. One variety, GS-Bounty, has been released and is being seed increased. Several other valuable resources were developed from the project including eleven novel protocols to screen wheat plants for various types of drought stress tolerance, salinity tolerance, seedling emergence from deeper depths, early seeding vigor, grain quality and other traits. Also, two fast breeding methods were optimized to transfer genes quickly and efficiently into desirable genetic backgrounds. Now the company is in the process of replacing currently used dwarfing genes with the new genes around the globe with initial focus on USA, Egypt, and SE Asia. Replacing currently used dwarfing genes with the new genes is expected to revolutionize wheat production. In the process, the startup company Geneshifters has grown to a mature company with its own 9000 sq ft facility containing a fully functional molecular biology lab, growth chambers, greenhouses, multiple locations for field evaluations and many partnerships and collaborations.

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2022
Modified by: Sukhwinder Singh

Images (1 of )
  • Advantage of the new dwarfing genes in comparison to the currently used genes under drought stress. Rht1Rht2 lacks any dwarfing gene while other plants with ?rht? name have different combinations of currently used rht genes. Another susceptible dwarfing gene GSD9 is also shown for comparison.
    Geneshifters, LLC
    Copyrighted
    Sukhwinder Singh
    Drought tolerance of new dwarfing genes
  • Comparison of old and new dwarfing genes for the dynamic nature of root growth in response to water stress. New dwarfing gene (GSD8) showing excellent root growth in response to decreasing water level. �-P� at the end of a name represent the corresponding wildtype parent lacking the dwarfing gene.
    Geneshifters, LLC
    Copyrighted
    Sukhwinder Singh
    Dynamic root growth in response to water level
  • GSD16 dwarf line showed the highest as well as the fastest emergence from deep sowing (marked by double asterisk) compared to other lines. GSD13 and GSD12 are the other two lines with good emergence and speed.
    Geneshifters, LLC
    Copyrighted
    Sukhwinder Singh
    Wheat emergence from deep planting depth
